title: Petition: Do not remove LGBT content from the Relationships Education curriculum

last_post.content:
I am going to keep posting about this until we get to 100,000 signatures.

Yes, it's another one of these damned post from that obsessed woman, I am sorry.

As I write there are 89,316 signatures. The linear trend line of signatures from Tuesday 31 January gives an equation of
y = 861.45x + 82873.
That means the date for hitting 100,000 votes has drifted out by another day to Saturday 18 February. I know we can do better than this. The last we thing we want is the petition to remove LGBT content from the curriculum to be debated and our opinion not to be heard.

Please sign if you are in the UK and please boost if you are not.

May I take this opportunity to thank each and everyone of the 1,260 people that have boosted this post so far. 💖 💖

Petition: Do not remove LGBT content from the Relationships Education curriculum

https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/631529

#TransRightsAreHumanrRghts #Trans

title: Shift Happens: A book about keyboards

last_post.content:
Shift Happens launches tomorrow on Kickstarter, 9 am PST – get notified via the pre-launch project page: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/mwichary/shift-happens?ref=2h744m See also: https://shifthappens.site

What is?
• An authoritative exploration of keyboards from typewriters to the current day, spanning 150 years
• 1,216-page, two-volume book in a slipcover
• Over 1,300 photos
• Written by @mwichary
• Edited by yours truly
• Every computer keyboard you love? Almost certainly in there. Every typewriter you desire? Also present.

title: Bring back personal blogging

last_post.content:
"The biggest reason personal blogs need to make a comeback is a simple one: we should all be in control of our own platforms.

If what is happening on Twitter hasn’t demonstrated it, our relationship with these social media platforms is tenuous at best. The thing we are using to build our popularity today could very well be destroyed and disappear from the internet tomorrow, and then what?

What happens to all the content you have created?"

https://www.theverge.com/23513418/bring-back-personal-blogging

title: Decoding the Hype About AI – The Markup

last_post.content:
ChatGPT writes truth as a side effect of its primary goal: persuading.

“I call it a bullshit generator, as have others as well. We mean this not in a normative sense but in a relatively precise sense. We mean that it is trained to produce plausible text. It is very good at being persuasive, but it’s not trained to produce true statements.” ~ Arvind Narayanan

https://themarkup.org/hello-world/2023/01/28/decoding-the-hype-about-ai

title: Facebook secretly killed users batteries, worker claims in lawsuit

last_post.content:
When George Hayward was as Facebook data-scientist, his bosses ordered him to run a #NegativeTest, updating Messenger to deliberately drain users' batteries, in order to determine how power-hungry various parts of the apps were. Hayward refused, and FB fired him, and he sued:

https://nypost.com/2023/01/28/facebook-fires-worker-who-refused-to-do-negative-testing-awsuit/

--

title: Open Syllabus: Explorer

last_post.content: @quinnanya @miriamkp @scott_bot @bc_butler @zoeleblanc @andrewpiper @ryancordell Quinn brings up a feature of Viral Text that I think is paradigmatic of many projects that decide that the output of text- and data-mining in the humanities should not be (exclusively) a screenshot Figure B on a traditional paper. Once you turn this kind of work interactive online, then it doubles as a "discovery mechanism" to use the language of library science: Half new knowledge, half service. You could also call it a para-text like @sramsay does in _An Algorithmic Cricitism_. In short, any and all projects that do this can be used as examples. "Viral Texts" is a great one. I use "Open Syllabus Explorer and Galaxy" myself to make this point. Mostly because I was a PI back in the day. https://opensyllabus.org/

title: Myspace loses all content uploaded before 2016

last_post.content:
Reminder that whatever you store on an internet site will one day vanish, even if it's stored on the largest and richest site in the world:

"Myspace, the once mighty social network, has lost every single piece of content uploaded to its site before 2016, including millions of songs, photos and videos with no other home on the internet."

https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2019/mar/18/myspace-loses-all-content-uploaded-before-2016

Please don't rely on internet services to exist forever, they will all disappear eventually.

Try to store copies of important stuff offline if you can. Music, video, photos etc can all be stored locally.

title: Elon Musk says bots with ‘good content’ can use Twitter’s API for free

last_post.content:
Does Twitter’s free tier for the Twitter API affect our dropping Twitter support from NetNewsWire?

https://www.theverge.com/2023/2/5/23586577/elon-musk-bots-good-content-twitters-api-free

It does not. The big reason is that that free tier is write-only — and NetNewsWire is a reading app.

But even if they did make another change and allow for some free use for readers, we could never rely on it. Twitter has proven that it’s an unacceptable partner.

title: Creatures That Don’t Conform – Lucy Jones

last_post.content:
' “Mum! Mum! I think I’ve found a slime mold!”

“No. NO??!!!” I shouted, sticking my feet halfway into my trainers and rushing out to my six-year-old daughter in our garden....

She pointed out a mass of tiny maroon tubes, clumped together on old damp pallets. The wood was loose, so I picked it up and fetched my hand lens. It was a mother-fucking slime mold. In my garden. In my garden! Holy shit. The hunt was really on. '

#SlimeMolds #myxomycetes

https://emergencemagazine.org/essay/creatures-that-dont-conform/

title: Why I Don't Care if Students Use GPT

last_post.content:
I've been spending a lot of time thinking about #ChatGPT and academic assessment and why I am not so concerned about it (at the college level). It's not that ChatGPT is bad for education. It's that our education system is built upon a basis wherein we do assessment wrong.

What @hoffman writes in his blog below comes close to how I think of things (thanks for saving me a lot of time writing my thoughts down!)

http://write.guyhoffman.com/why-i-dont-care-if-students-use-gpt

title: https://github.com/tootsdk/tootsdk

last_post.content:
Hey folks, TootSDK is now public! 🚀

TootSDK is a Swift package for creating apps that interact with Mastodon, Pleroma and other Fediverse APIs.

It handles the data model and network calls, with lovely async/await based calls.

The SDK is still young. There are plenty of API calls still to add. The foundations are strong, and TootSDK is very useful already.

Contributions and PRs are more than welcome!

Check out the repo here: https://github.com/tootsdk/tootsdk :mastodance: :apple:

#swift #iosdev #vapor #serversideswift #appkit #uikit #swiftui

title: magazine.amstat.org/blog/2018/...

last_post.content:
A brief #introduction: I'm a data scientist w/ a math+stats background. I've been with the Wikimedia Foundation (the non-profit behind Wikipedia) for 7y+ and I've been managing since 2021

You may have read my guide on hiring: https://magazine.amstat.org/blog/2018/09/01/hiring-a-data-scientist/

I’ve written about my journey as an individual contributor (back in 2017) on my blog: https://mpopov.com/blog/2017/09/21/the-journey-so-far/

I've authored a few R packages, most notably WikidataQueryServiceR

You can learn about my team and what we do at https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Product_Analytics

title: Making SQLite extensions pip install-able

last_post.content:
Ferociously useful work here from @alexgarciaxyz: https://observablehq.com/@asg017/making-sqlite-extensions-pip-install-able

Alex figured out how to bundle compiled SQLite extensions in per-platform Python wheels and ship them to PyPI - so now you can do things like "pip install sqlite-regex" to get his SQLite regex functions, which he implemented in Rust

More notes here: https://simonwillison.net/2023/Feb/6/making-sqlite-extensions-pip-install-able/
